title: Touching rescue of Dominga, the illegally trafficked bear so depressed that she's gone bald
text:
News Touching rescue of Dominga, the illegally trafficked bear so depressed that she's gone bald The spectacled bear was trapped in a cramped zoo and suffered crippling loneliness but has now been transferred to the Amazon to start a new life Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Touching moment bald bear Dominga is put back into the jungle Share this video   Thank you for subscribing!   
Illegally torn from the wild by traffickers when she was just a cub, Dominga the spectacled bear was left a shadow of her former self, trapped in a cramped, remote zoo. 
While she should have a striking glossy coat like other spectacled Peruvian bears - tragically, sociable Dominga suffered such crippling loneliness she developed stress-induced alopecia and has lost most of her fur due to anxiety. 
The adorable creature - the same type of bear as Paddington - was found just half the size she should have been and suffering with overgrown nails and painful skin fungus. 
But now Dominga has been rescued in the nick of time and is starting a new life in the Amazon jungle where rescuers hope she will be able to get back to full health. 
Elderly Dominga has been left with just a tuft of hair on her head, making her almost unrecognisable as a member of the distinctive species. Read More Dominga is rubbed with ointment to help with her skin fungus Workers carry her cage 
Jan Creamer, the president of Animal Defenders International, who helped rescue Dominga, says her “remaining hair looks like a very endearing Mohican cut” but her anxiety must be reduced for a full body of hair to successfully grow back. 
It is thought the problem was sparked when her sister died during their confinement in the zoo in Peru four years ago. 
Jan adds: “Alopecia in captive female spectacled bears is known to be associated with stress, and we are told it started after her sister died, as did her weight loss,” says Jan. “She was clearly very lonely without her sister. In the Peruvian zoo before her transfer Dominga was sedated for the move 
“We know that an environment more natural for her species and having the company of other spectacled bears will make a huge difference to her physical and psychological health.” 
Thanks to the work of Animal Defenders International, Dominga will finally live happily as a wild animal after her traumatic kidnap. 
After a gruelling 500-mile journey over the Andes, 14-year-old Dominga has been transported to her new home in a lush jungle in the Amazon – the natural habitat for spectacled bears. The rescue party are checked over by the army 
Animal Defenders International came to her aid and launched an emergency appeal to fund her complex four-day relocation after finding her so sick in the enclosure. 
The team had to sedate her before the trip, in order to trim her overgrown claws with huge clippers and an industrial file. She also received a complete body massage with specialist creams to treat the fungus and soothe her cracked skin. Dominga is a real-life Paddington Bear (Photo: BBC) 
“Dominga was very good on the journey and I found the most important thing to keep her happy was an endless supply of large red grapes – that seemed to cure any sign of nerves or boredom!” says Jan. 
“We gave her deep straw and a large blanket in her travel crate and she made herself a nice nest.” 
And now Dominga is like a new bear, having settled into her home inside the jungle in the south-eastern Peruvian department of Madre de Dios. Her new place not only has natural vegetation, but boasts a cave, a pool and some platforms for climbing. Rescuers kept the bear happy by feeding her grapes during the boat trip Dominga being carried into the forest at the end of her journey Read More Cholita the real-life Paddington bear gets a safe forest home after a life of circus torture 
Jan recalls seeing Dominga in her natural habitat for the first time. “She immediately climbed to the top of her enclosure and climbed along the top of the fence, before coming down to inspect all the platforms, toys and her cave,” she says. 
“She is very inquisitive and perhaps a little bit naughty – she has already pulled up some plants by the roots, dug a couple of holes, and tried chewing a water pipe. She expects everyone who walks by to be carrying grapes for her! Looking chilled in the travel crate (Photo: Publicity Picture) Dominga was sad and lonely but now it is hoped she will improve It is hoped Dominga will make friends with another bear, Cholita 
“Like Paddington Bear, she has a lovely personality and is very friendly.” 
And Dominga never has to be lonely again. 
Her enclosure is next door to 27-year-old Cholita, another female spectacled bear . 
Taricaya has built a special meet–and–greet tunnel between their enclosures so the pair can become pals. New pal Cholita (Photo: Animal Defenders International) 
And Dominga’s new life may even lead to her fur returning. “It may well grow back,” says Jan. 
“It depends on her diet, reducing her stress and making her feel more contented, which she seems to be now. 
“This is our expression of love – a lonely, elderly lady bear finally able to see her own kind and hear a voice she can understand.” Like us on Facebook
